children.name: right
children.definition: when you should be able to have or do sth, according to the law or according to moral ideas: quyền
examples: Free speech is a basic right in a democratic society.

children.name: right to
examples: I disagree, but I respect his right to his opinion.

children.name: the right to do sth
examples: Women all over the world fought long and hard for the right to vote.

children.name: the right of veto/ action/ self-determination/ free speech etc
examples: The executive council has the right of veto over the management’s policy.

children.name: have the right to sth
examples: Everyone the right to a good basic education.:

children.name: entitlement
children.definition: the official right to have or receive sth, especially money, that you get from a government or an employer : quyền (có được, nhận được)
examples: Many people are still not aware of the entitlements they may be able to receive.

children.name: entitlement to: quyền đối với
examples: The amount of money you earn does not affect your entitlement to child benefit for your children.

children.name: holiday/ pension etc entitlement: quyền nghỉ lễ/nghỉ hưu
examples: Holiday entitlements for temporary workers are less than for permanent staff.

children.name: claim
children.definition: the right to have or be given sth because you were its original owner, or because you have a moral right to it: quyền yêu sách

children.name: claim to:quyền yêu sách đối với
examples: No one can dispute the Mohawks’ claim to this land.
His claim to the house was finally recognized by the court.

children.name: by right
children.definition: if sth is yours by right, you have a moral right to have it or be given it: có quyền (sở hữu)
examples: The money is yours by right.
He believes that he is entitled by right to inherit from his father, despite his father’s will.
Developers were met by angry locals protesting that the land was theirs by right.

children.name: equal
children.definition: people who are equal have the same rights as each other and are treated in the same way as each other; if people get equal treatment, pay etc, they are all treated in the same way or get paid the same money: bình đẳng như nhau
examples: Democracy is based on the idea that all members of society are equal.
equally[adv]
People should be treated equally, regardless of their race or sex.

children.name: equal rightsthe idea that all types of people in society should have the same rights and should be treated fairly and equally : quyền bình đẳng
examples: Black protestors campaigned for equal rights throughout the 1960s.

children.name: equal opportunitiesthe idea that all types of people in society should have the same chances of employment : cơ hội bình đẳng
examples: Companies are being urged to do more to promote equal opportunities in the workplace.

children.name: equal pay
examples: The Treaty of Rome states that men and women shall receive equal pay for equal work.

children.name: equality
children.definition: when all people have the same rights and opportunities in society and are treated equally: sự bình đẳng
examples: Greater equality was one of the aims of the post-war government.
equalitybetweenthe sexes
racial/ sexual equality
the struggle for sexual equality
It will take more than laws to bring about genuine racial equality.

children.name: on an equal footing
children.definition: people, countries, or organizations that are on an equal footing in a particular situation are being treated as equal, even though this would not happen in other places or situations: bình đẳng
examples: It’s the beginning of the course, so you’re all on an equal footing.

children.name: place/ put sb on an equal footingtreat them in the same way
examples: It wasn’t until 1928, that divorce laws were reformed to put men and women on an equal footing.

children.name: equal
children.definition: sb who has the same rights, advantages, and position in society as sb else, with the result that they can have equal respect for each other: người cùng địa vị, vai vế, etc.
examples: Most women these days want marriage to be a partnership of equals.
As an all-round athlete hehas no equal(= no-one else is as good) .

children.name: peer
children.definition: sb who has the same background or position in society as you - used especially in technical or official contexts: người cùng địa vị, ngang hàng, bạn bè
examples: The jury system gives you the basic right to be judged by your peers.
Everyone wants to be successful in the eyes of their peers.
At about three years old, children begin to take an interest in their peers.

children.name: parity
children.definition: formal the state of being measurably equal, for example by receiving equal wages or having equal numbers of jobs as another group - used especially in political contexts: bằng nhau, tương đương

children.name: parity with
examples: Part-time workers are demanding parity with their full-time colleagues.
Middle class blacks in the US have not yet achieved parity with whites in graduate school entries.

children.name: the political and social rights that everyone should have
rights
children.definition: the political and social freedom that everyone in a country should have: quyền
examples: Every individual should have basic rights
rights of
Some motorcyclists saw the helmet law as an infringement on the rights of the individual
women’s /workers’/ victims’ etc rights
Laws enacted in the past ten years have gradually taken away workers’ rights
Allred is an attorney who has gained a national reputation fighting for women’s rights.

children.name: civil rights
children.definition: the rights that every person should have, such as the right to vote or be treated equally and fairly by the law, whatever their sex, race, or religion quyền công dân
examples: She had been actively involved in the struggle for civil rights in the US in the '60s.
The President has agreed to talks with civil rights campaigners.
The civil rights movement illustrates how people can change the constitution of their country.
Civil rights include freedom, equality in law and in employment, and the right to vote.

children.name: human rights
children.definition: the basic right that all people should have, including freedom and the right to be treated fairly and without cruelty by their government: quyền con người, nhân quyền
examples: The Court ruled that hitting children was an abuse of human rights.
A number of leading human rights activists were arrested yesterday.
The regime has a long record of human rights violations.
She's claiming that her detention by the police was a violation of her human rights.

children.name: equal rights
children.definition: the rights of every person to be treated fairly and equally by the law or by society, whatever their sex, race, religion, or social position: quyền bình đẳng.
examples: The battle for equal rights for women is not yet over.
The Americans were the first to make law the principle of equal rights for every individual.
Homosexual men and women are campaigning for equal rights.

children.name: equal opportunities
children.definition: the right of every person to have a chance to get a job, go to university etc, whatever their sex, race, or social position: cơ hội bình đẳng,cơ hội như nhau
examples: Only in a completely classless society can there be equal opportunities for everyone.

children.name: equal opportunities legislation/ programs etc
examples: Certain jobs were dominated by men until the equal opportunities legislation of the 1970s.
The advert said 'We are an equal opportunities employer'.

children.name: civil liberties
children.definition: the rights of any citizen to do whatever they want as long as they respect the rights of other people, without having to ask anyone’s permission, and the right to keep their personal information private: quyền tự do dân sự
examples: The banning of public meetings was held to be a denial of civil liberties.
The ability of this software to gather information about individuals through the Web is worrying to civil liberties groups.

children.name: voice
children.definition: the right or ability to express an opinion, to vote, or to influence decisions : tiếng nói
examples: The committee representsthevoiceofthe students.
Developing countries are demanding a stronger voice (= right to express opinions) in the debate.
Parents shouldhave a voicein deciding how their children are educated.

children.name: when all people have the same rights and are treated fairly
equal
children.definition: /ˈiːkwəl/  people who are equal have the same rights as each other and are treated in the same way as each other; if people get equal treatment, pay etc, they are all treated in the same way or get paid the same money:
examples: equally[adverb] một cách bình đẳng
▪ People should be treated equally, regardless of their race or sex.

children.name: bình đẳng ,ngang nhau, như nhau
examples: ▪ Democracy is based on the idea that all members of society are equal.

children.name: equal rightsthe idea that all types of people in society should have the same rights and should be treated fairly and equally : quyền bình đẳng
examples: ▪ Black protestors campaigned for equal rights throughout the 1960s.

children.name: equal opportunitiesthe idea that all types of people in society should have the same chances of employment : cơ hội như nhau
examples: ▪ Companies are being urged to do more to promote equal opportunities in the workplace.

children.name: equal pay : lương ngang nhau
examples: ▪ The Treaty of Rome states that men and women shall receive equal pay for equal work.

children.name: equality
children.definition: /ɪˈkwɒlɪti, ɪˈkwɒlətiǁɪˈkwɑː-/  when all people have the same rights and opportunities in society and are treated equally:
examples: sự bình đẳng
▪ Greater equality was one of the aims of the post-war government.
racial/sexual equality bình đẳng tôn giáo, giới tính
▪ the struggle for sexual equality
▪ It will take more than laws to bring about genuine racial equality.

children.name: believing in equal rights for women
feminism
children.definition: a set of beliefs based on the principle that women are equal to men and should be treated equally: thuyết nam nữ bình đẳng
examples: There were many close links between social reform movements and feminism.
the civilising influence of feminism
The feminists marched in thousands when David Laing urged married women to give up their jobs and stay at home.
radical feminist[sb with extreme feminist views]
In the 1960's I saw myself as a revolutionary and a radical feminist.
feminist[adj]
the early feminist movement

children.name: feminist[
examples: C noun] sb who believes strongly in the principle that men and women should be treated equally, and that society should be changed so that this can happen:

children.name: a special right belonging to one person or group
privilege
children.definition: a special right or advantage given to a person or group, because of their high social position, because they are a member of a club etc: đặc ân
examples: A good education should not just be a privilege of the rich.
privileged[adj] đặc cách
Only privileged club members those who have privileges can sit in the Royal Pavilion to watch matches.

children.name: the privilege of doing sth
examples: If prisoners behave well they are allowed the privilege of visiting their families at the weekend.

children.name: give sb a privilege
examples: Why should famous people be given special privileges?

children.name: lose a privilege
examples: If the chores aren’t done by the time the timer goes off, the kids lose privileges such as TV time.

children.name: prerogative
children.definition: formala special right that only a particular person or group has because of their importance or position: đặc quyền
examples: In the old days, a university education was the prerogative of the rich.
Skiing used to be the prerogativeofthe rich, but now a far wider range of people do it.
the RoyalPrerogative (= the special rights of the ruling king or queen)
prerogative to do sth: đặc quyền để làm gì
The governor has the prerogative to free prisoners.

children.name: birthright
children.definition: a right that you should have because you have been born into a particular family, country, class etc: quyền thừa hưởng, quyền tập ấm

children.name: The President ended his speech by saying ‘Dignity and self-respect are the birthright of every American citizen.’
examples: She seemed to regard an easy, comfortable life as some kind of birthright.

children.name: have or give sb a legal right
have the right
children.definition: to be legally or officially allowed to do or have sth: có quyền
examples: have the right to do sth: có quyền để làm gì
People should have a right to know what is on their credit history
We have a constitutional right to defend ourselves, our family, and our property.
have the right to
Olivia felt she had a right to information about her illness.

children.name: be entitled to
children.definition: to be legally allowed to have sth or do sth: được phép, có quyền, được hưởng
examples: The public is entitled to information about how public money is spent.

children.name: be entitled to do sth
examples: You are legally entitled to take faulty goods back to the store where you bought them.
Your landlord is not entitled to charge you for the remainder of the month’s rent.

children.name: give sb the right
children.definition: to legally or officially allow sb to do or have sth:

children.name: give sb the right to
examples: This government programme gives families on low incomes the right to extra financial help.

children.name: give sb the right to do sth
examples: The new regulations give dissatisfied customers the right to receive a full refund.

children.name: entitle
children.definition: to legally or officially allow sb to do or have sth : ban quyền,

children.name: entitle sb to sth
examples: Being a member entitles you to discounts on tickets.

children.name: entitle sb to do sth
examples: Ethiopian Jews were entitled to immigrate to Israel under the Law of Return.

children.name: within your rights
children.definition: to have a legal right to do sth, although it may seem unfair or unreasonable: có quyền
examples: If Mrs Cobb wanted to take the company to court for unfair dismissal, she’d be within her rights.

children.name: within your rights to do sth
examples: If your actions have disturbed other tenants, your landlady is within her rights to give you notice to stop the actions or leave.
I think I'm quite within my rightstodemand a full refund.

children.name: unequal
children.definition: unequal treatment, relationships, conditions etc are unfair to some of the people involved because they do not have equal rights or advantages: không bình đẳng
examples: The unequal distribution of wealth is a feature of our system of government.
When people are forced to compete on unequal terms they become resentful.
It was an unequal relationship. He was rich, powerful and experienced -- I was very young and naive.
